{"step_by_step_thinking": "The most commonly used route of administration of heparin for post-operative thromboprophylaxis is typically subcutaneous. Heparin is a medication used to prevent blood clots, and it is commonly administered subcutaneously as it allows for slow and continuous absorption into the bloodstream. Intravenous administration may be used in certain situations, such as in critically ill patients or during surgery, but it is not the most commonly used route for post-operative thromboprophylaxis. Inhalational and intramuscular routes are not typically used for heparin administration.", "answer_choice": "A"}
